I feel attackedhttps://twitter.com/nicolefv/status/1088470375522914304 …My brain does this thing where I spin on problems I haven't solved.

Sometimes it's DOPE: I used to debug code in my sleep. I do tricky research design in the shower. I figure out weird algos on walks.

Sometimes it's AWFUL: I'll spin & spin & spin. It might just be unsolvable.

Imagine if every method returned object. What's on it can change at any time. Need something that's not on there? Tough luck. Want to cast it as a type? Tough luck, they're anonymous or internal. What's the name of the event? Go search source code.

That's DiagnosticSource.

I looked today, but it seems that all of my (and others') points about this API haven't really gone anywhere (discussion here: https://github.com/StackExchange/StackExchange.Redis/issues/833 …)

I'm not upset about this. I'm sad. Because it's so fucking straightforward to fix. The EF team has been the only one to do so.

I got a feature request to have MiniProfiler show HttpClient requests via DiagnosticSource...but years later we're still on internal names, anonymous types, and brittle APIs :(

Internal names: https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/blob/master/src/System.Net.Http/src/System/Net/Http/DiagnosticsHandlerLoggingStrings.cs#L12 …
Anon types: https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/blob/fe6e895de1fe78c5e677895a1dcf1f6339561153/src/System.Net.Http/src/System/Net/Http/DiagnosticsHandler.cs#L144-L150 …
Or even lower! We had servers clocking to 0.13GHz due to a bad BIOS. Was hella fun watching @marcgravell tuning code, while unaware of this.

Software is not a craft.

Nor is it an art.

Nor is it engineering, or architecture, or anything we've ever before.

I now have words for what development is: the practice of symmathesy.https://medium.com/@jessitron/the-origins-of-opera-and-the-future-of-programming-bcdaf8fbe960 …

Even if you have technical writers, docs are a community effort. Tech writers can develop the documentation platform, set standards and mentor devs on writing (and, of course, write some amount of docs themselves), but everyone can and should contribute.

Codes of conduct are like infra as code: declaring our intentions helps us reach them. 
@schmonz #DevOpsDaysNYCpic.twitter.com/ylhOLErx1p

From a diagram, to readable terraform (if you read tf) via http://Modules.tf , to reality in AWS. @antonbabenko #DevOpsDaysNYC 
I like the trend toward generating code the way a human would write it, so a human can take it over.

"I'm a partially reformed wiseass."
OH at #devopsdaysNYC

Docs:
1) Service Overview: "Should I be reading these docs?"
2) Tutorial: "How do I do _?" prereqs, steps, identify success, what's next
3) Reference: "What are -all- my options?"
4) Troubleshooting: Solve this error message.
@evpari #devopsdaysNYC

Your job, as a software engineer is not to write code. It's to use software and computers to solve problems. How can you do that if you do not understand the domain of the problem or those operating in it?

Not true. Empathy is required, especially if you plan to deal with customers. If you're building without empathy you're only building for yourself.https://twitter.com/venatiodecorus/status/1088933641063931906 …Empathy is not a technical requirement. Sure it’s nice to have but teams can work without it.
Hot take: Emotional intelligence is as important, if not more important than dev skills.

*sigh* okay:

Frontend dev: hard.
Backend dev: hard.
Language design: hard.
Writing docs: hard.
HTML/CSS: hard.
UI design: hard.
Communicating: hard.
Leading people: hard.
Management: hard.

It's all hard. Each one of these is an endless rabbit hole. And it's not a competition.

How many lines of code are in Google's WebRTC implementation (https://webrtc.googlesource.com/src )? As of the end of 2018, it consists of 1.21M lines of code (up from 1.08M in 2017); for a comparison, this is 3x as much code as the Space Shuttle software.

When making the choice between lateinit vs nullable.  Ask yourself, "Is there a legitimate use case where this could variable could be null."  If yes, use a nullable type. 

If you see lots of ::isInitialized expressions everywhere, its probably a code smell. #AndroidDev #Kotlin

Also released Butter Knife 10.0.0 (aka BK X (pronouned mavericks)) which is the same as 9.0.0 but *only* supports AndroidX-based builds.

Released Butter Knife 9.0.0 with AndroidX support, an entirely reflection-free runtime (i.e., no Class.forName), tons of bug fixes, and an experimental new entirely reflection-based runtime.

Sam's blog post spurred me to start the slow process of converting Tivi over to using buildSrc for keeping dependencies in check.

I don't want to convert to using Gradle Kotlin just yet, but you can get most of the way with Java interfaces 

https://github.com/chrisbanes/tivi/blob/bd5e9405bb675ff9c6dad70092510ed5d36f51e0/buildSrc/src/main/java/app/tivi/buildsrc/Libs.java …https://twitter.com/HandstandSam/status/1080485711386681344 …Even the AOSP (Android Open Source Project) manages dependencies with Kotlin + buildSrc in the latest code: https://android.googlesource.com/platform/frameworks/support/+/androidx-master-dev/buildSrc/src/main/kotlin/androidx/build/dependencies/Dependencies.kt …

Check out my blog about it as well: https://handstandsam.com/2018/02/11/kotlin-buildsrc-for-better-gradle-dependency-management/ … pic.twitter.com/gnKOx4Ok2r
Finally here's the code. You can see that I've removed some custom listener code which had much the same effect.https://github.com/chrisbanes/tivi/pull/257/files …
You can see my conversion here https://github.com/chrisbanes/tivi/pull/256 …

2) Leaves window to do another task while script runs.
3) Comes back to see script failed because I didn't pass the right args.
4) Goto 1.
Every. Dam. Time.
